Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as exaggerating the extent to which people were able to easily climb the fence by stating that it contradicts Trump's claim that it "can't be climbed."
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide sufficient evidence or support to fully validate the assertion that people were easily climbing the fence.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the images and footage shown were representative of the specific fence that Trump was referring to, when in fact they were from different stretches of border fencing.
Exist alternative explanation: There could be alternative explanations for the footage and images, such as the possibility that the fence was not fully constructed or fortified at the time of the climb.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts Trump's assertion that the fence "can't be climbed" by presenting evidence of people successfully scaling it.
Falters at times: The claim may falter in its presentation by using older footage and images that do not accurately reflect the current state of the fence.
Understate: The claim may understate the complexity and effectiveness of the border wall by focusing solely on instances of people climbing it, without considering other aspects of its design and purpose.
